title: Power of a car climbing up a hill

content.question: If air resistance is negligible, the power required by a car to drive at constant speed up a hill inclined at <math alttext="30 degrees " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the horizontal is <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. What power is required by the car to drive at the same constant speed up a hill inclined at <math alttext="60 degrees " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to the horizontal?

choices.label: Greater than <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> but less than <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

Less than <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> but greater than <math alttext="the fraction P over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: Greater than <math alttext="P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> but less than <math alttext="2 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>P</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
